properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Goulburn River from Eildon to Seymour
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River from Eildon to Seymour.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT DOWNSTREAM LAKE EILDON AND SEYMOUR

MINOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON EARLY FRIDAY MORNING

In the 24 hours to12:00 pm Thursday, rainfall totals of up to 25 mm have been observed across the Goulburn River catchment. Showers are continuing to ease, with a further 5-10 mm possible in the upper catchment.

Flow levels from Lake Eildon are expected to reach 17,000 ML/d at around 1 pm Thursday afternoon.

Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River from Downstream Lake Eildon to Seymour. Minor flooding is occurring at Trawool.

The Goulburn River Downstream Lake Eildon is currently at 3.14 metres and rising, with minor flooding. The Goulburn River Downstream Lake Eildon is likely to remain above the minor flood level (3.00 metres) for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.

The Goulburn River at Seymour is currently at 3.81 metres and rising, with minor flooding. The Goulburn River at Seymour is likely to remain above the minor flood level (3.80 metres) for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.

Hughes Creek:

River levels remain elevated along Hughes Creek.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock, pumps and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
Eildon to Seymour: At Minor flood level 3.8 m on the Seymour Gauge:

  • The Goulburn River Caravan Park at Seymour may start to flood low lying parts.
  • The Caravan Parks at Molesworth and the Breakaway Caravan Park at Acheron has enacted their emergency plans.
  • Localised flooding along the river frontage between Kings Park and the old Hume Highway.   
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point between Whorouly to Wangaratta
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point between Whorouly to Wangaratta.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT WANGARATTA
MODERATE FLOODING EASING ALONG THE KING RIVER AT DOCKER ROAD BRIDGE
MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING ALONG THE BUFFALO RIVER AT LAKE BUFFALO DOWNSTREAM

Moderate flooding is occurring along the Ovens River at Wangaratta, where river levels are nearing a peak slightly below the major flood level. Moderate flooding is easing along the King River at Docker Rd Bridge. Minor flooding continues along the Ovens River at Rocky Point and along the King River at downstream Lake William Hovell.

No significant rainfall is forecast across the Ovens and King Rivers catchment over the next few days.

Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point:
Moderate flooding is occurring along the Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point. The Ovens River at Wangaratta is currently at 12.60 metres and near its peak, with moderate flooding. The Ovens River at Wangaratta is likely to peak around 12.60 metres Friday morning, slightly below the major flood level (12.70 m)

Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:

  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
  • Decide and get ready to evacuate if it becomes necessary or you feel unsafe.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation. 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground IF STILL SAFE TO DO.
  • If in a flood risk area, be prepared to move household items to higher ground, on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
  • If you are camping close to the Ovens River, you need to move to higher ground, away from waterways. You may be at risk of flooding or your access road to safety cut by floodwater. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services .
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area:  

A Community Update meeting was streamed live over Facebook and recorded at 2pm yesterday. Due to current flooding closing roads etc this "virtual" meeting with the latest information, it has been recorded for further sharing. Please find attached a YouTube link to this video: Wangaratta Video Update 5 Oct 2023

A sandbag collection point opened in Wangaratta on Thursday morning on the corner of Handley St and Greta Rd (in the park next to the police station). Sandbags are limited to 25 per address for blocking toilets, vents, doorways etc. Check out how to sandbag correctly and watch the short video at www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/at-home

The Wangaratta Local Flood Guide is available to check your flood risk. It also has maps and information about how to get prepared, your Emergency Kit and what happens in and around Wangaratta when floods happen. Go to https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/at-home

Impacts in and around Wangaratta:
  • At Major flood level in Wangaratta, flooding above floor level of some low lying homes and sheds are likely to occur in a few locations. 
  • Evacuation of a few houses may be required.
  • A small number of properties are likely to be impacted and possibly become isolated between in Doweling Lane

Road Closures: 
  • Many roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding, especially the Great Alpine Rd at Yellow Creek near Wangaratta, travel via the Detour Road bypass. 
  • Oxley Flats Rd, some roads in the Whorouly area. 
  • For more information on road closures, see below and go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

Flood Levels in Wangaratta:

At 11.9m, Minor flood level:
Water up to Yogis Chin in APEX Park. Apex Park and farmland along the Ovens, King and possibly the Fifteen Mile Creek floodplains north, south and east of Wangaratta begin flooding. Bike paths and walking tracks around and downstream of Apex Park and the Northern Beaches are closed. Many riverside carparks are closed.
At 12.4m, Moderate flood level:
Water up to Yogis Mouth in APEX Park. Extensive flooding through Apex Park. Residents in Wilson and Parfitt Rd levees are advised to prepare to evacuate (Unless levee damage happens before this). Shallow flooding to Pinkerton Cres and backyards along Templeton St and Baker St. Widespread, deep flooding outside of the Parfitt Rd levee. 
At 12.7m, Major level flood:
6 cm lower than the Dec 2010 flood.
Water up to Yogi's nose in APEX Park. Extensive road closures, including: Wilson Rd (outside levee area), Peechelba Rd at Seven Bridges, River Rd, Markwood-Everton Rd, Milawa-Tarrawingee Rd, Markwood-Tarrawingee Rd, Billabong Dve, Oxley Flats Rd, Stamps Lane area. Widespread flooding around the airport and along the Ovens River flats north of Wangaratta to Peechelba and Bundalong and into the Stamps Lane area north of Wangaratta.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 08:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for Yea River, King Parrot Creek and Sunday Creek.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Wednesday, rainfall totals up to 35 mm have been observed across the Goulburn River catchment.

Showers are forecast to continue easing into late Thursday morning and afternoon, with a further 5-10 mm possible in the upper catchment.

In the 24 hours to 12:00 pm Thursday, rainfall totals of up to 25 mm have been observed across the Goulburn River catchment. Showers are continuing to ease, with a further 5-10 mm possible in the upper catchment.

Yea River:

River level rises are easing but remain elevated along the Yea River.

King Parrot Creek:

River levels are easing but remain elevated along King Parrot Creek.

Sunday Creek:

River levels are easing but remain elevated along Sunday Creek.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Low lying areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Some local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir.
This Advice replaces the Moderate Flood Warning issued at 1:06pm today Thursday 05 October.  

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT CASEY WEIR AND BENALLA

Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir: 
  •  Minor flooding is occuring along the Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir. 
  •  The Broken River at Casey Weir peaked at 2.44 metres around 10:00am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 2.39 metres and steady, with minor flooding.  
  •  The Broken River at Casey Weir is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.10 m) during Thursday.
Broken River to Benalla: 
  •  Minor flooding is occuring along the Broken River to Benalla. The Broken River at Benalla is currently at 3.24 metres and steady, above the minor flood level.  
  •  The Broken River at Benalla is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) during Thursday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding may still be in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of one single-storey home has been reported in Benalla today. 
  • A small number of properties in Benalla became become isolated, however falling river levels today have seen road access re-open.
ROAD CLOSURES
  • The Midland Highway is closed at Stewarton Ackerley Ave and Arundel Street South (river end) in Benalla has been closed due to floodwater.  
  •  Benalla-Tatong Road (Samaria Road) closed due to flooding between Shawbrook Avenue and Hume Freeway Overpass 
  •  The Monash Bridge is now re-opened to traffic in both directions.
     For more information on road closures go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
For health information and support contact the below organisations: Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. Kids Helpine on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Culloden, Fernbank, Glenaladale, Iguana Creek, Moornapa, Munro, Stockdale, Walpa, Woodglen, Cobbannah, Lindenow South
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cobbannah, Culloden, Fernbank, Glenaladale, Iguana Creek, Lindenow South, Moornapa, Munro, Stockdale, Walpa, Woodglen and surrounding areas.

  • The bushfire at Duffy Rd, Briagolong is not yet under control.
  • Recent rain has dampened fire activity. However, there is still active fire within the area as logs and trees continue to burn.
  • You may see isolated pockets of flames and smoke over the burnt area.
  • Firefighters are monitoring the area.
  • Several roads are still closed due to active fire and hazardous trees.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
The following Roads are closed: 
  • Freestone Creek Road at Valencia Creek Road.
  • Valencia Creek Road at Marathon Road
  • Fernbank-Glenaladale Road at Princes Highway.
  • Stockdale Road at Briagolong-Stockdale Road
The following road has a reduced speed limit:
  • Beverleys Road.
Livestock:
  • East Gippsland Livestock Exchange in Bairnsdale wants Community to be aware their gates are open for safe respite of livestock at risk from the current bushfires and flood watch Zones .     
  • They will be holding cattle sales this Thursday and Friday so please contact Mal on 0417 707 540 for direction on where to pen them and leave feed.
Drinking water:
  • Smoke and ash may impact your tank water.
  • To avoid contamination, block off water tanks until the roof and gutters have been flushed by rain.
  • Follow the guide on the water.vic.gov.au website:
  • https://www.water.vic.gov.au/about-us/safety-and-emergencies/preparing-your-water-tank-before-and-after-bushfires
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

Incident Location: Duffy Rd, Briagolong
Issue Date: Thursday 05 October 2023, 07:44 pm
Next Update: Friday 06 October 2023, 06:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30550/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Cobbannah, Culloden, Fernbank, Glenaladale, Iguana Creek, Lindenow South, Moornapa, Munro, Stockdale, Walpa, Woodglen and surrounding areas.

- The bushfire at Duffy Rd, Briagolong is not yet under control.
- Recent rain has dampened fire activity. However, there is still active fire within the area as logs and trees continue to burn.
- You may see isolated pockets of flames and smoke over the burnt area.
- Firefighters are monitoring the area.
- Several roads are still closed due to active fire and hazardous trees.


There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is for Port of Sale.
  • An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return.
  • The Thomson River is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (3.00 m) early Friday morning and may reach the major flood level (4.00 m) late Friday morning.
It is not safe for people to return to Port of Sale. If you have not evacuated, you should now shelter in the highest location possible.
What you should do:

If you have not already evacuated:
  • Stay where you are and shelter in the highest location possible.
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already evacuated:
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe. The relief centre is located at the Gippsland Regional Sports Complex, 116 Cobains Road, Sale.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place for 12-24 hours or until floodwater has receded. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Flood levels remain above that of a single-storey home. 
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding. 
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • Rainfall totals of 1-5 mm are forecast for the catchment Thursday 05 October 2023.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Macalister River upstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

MINOR FLOODING EASING AT LICOLA 

River levels are easing upstream of Lake Glenmaggie. 

No significant rainfall has been recorded across the Macalister River catchment since 9:00 am Thursday. 

The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary. 

Macalister River upstream of Lake Glenmaggie: 
Minor flooding is occurring along the Macalister River upstream of Lake Glenmaggie. 

The Macalister River at Licola peaked at 4.09 metres (major flood level 3.60 metres) around 07:15 pm Wednesday 04 October and is currently at 2.87 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Macalister River at Licola is likely to fall below the minor flood level (2.70 m) Thursday evening. 

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • The Licola Road may be inundated by water in a number of places that will isolate the Licola community.         
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek.

Moderate flooding is occurring along the Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge.

Since 9:00 am Thursday, up to 5 mm of rainfall has been recorded across the Latrobe catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for next few days. 

This situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek: 
Moderate flooding is occurring along the Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek. 

The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is currently at 5.90 metres and steady, above the moderate flood level. The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is likely to remain above the moderate flood level (5.00 m) during Thursday into Friday.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT DOWNSTREAM LAKE EILDON AND SEYMOUR

MINOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON EARLY FRIDAY MORNING

In the 24 hours to 12:00 pm Thursday, rainfall totals of up to 25 mm have been observed across the Goulburn River catchment. Showers are continuing to ease, with a further 5-10 mm possible in the upper catchment.

Flow levels from Lake Eildon are expected to reach 17,000 ML/d at around 1 pm Thursday afternoon.

Minor flooding is possible along the Goulburn River at Shepparton. The Goulburn River at Shepparton is currently below the minor flood level (9.50 metres) at 4.87 metres and rising. 

The Goulburn River at Shepparton may reach the minor flood level (9.50 m) early Friday morning.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Watt Road and Raftery Road Shepparton start to flood at 8.75m.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT DOWNSTREAM OF LAKE GLENMAGGIE

The Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie peaked at 6.96 metres around 02:30 am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 4.61 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. Based on Southern Rural Water's planned releases from Lake Glenmaggie, the Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie is likely to remain above the moderate flood level (4.30 m) Thursday evening. 

The river level is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (4.30 m) during Friday as releases from Lake Glenmaggie are reduced further.

No significant rainfall has been recorded across the Macalister River catchment since 9:00 am Thursday.

The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Dont swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

Incident Location: Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie
Issue Date: Thursday 05 October 2023, 07:58 pm
Next Update: Friday 06 October 2023, 11:00 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30551/moreinfo

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT DOWNSTREAM OF LAKE GLENMAGGIE 

The Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie peaked at 6.96 metres around 02:30 am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 4.61 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. Based on Southern Rural Water's planned releases from Lake Glenmaggie, the Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie is likely to remain above the moderate flood level (4.30 m) Thursday evening. 

The river level is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (4.30 m) during Friday as releases from Lake Glenmaggie are reduced further. 

No significant rainfall has been recorded across the Macalister River catchment since 9:00 am Thursday.

The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary. 

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Broken River downstream of Casey Weir.
This Watch and Act message replaces the Minor flood warning issued at 1.50 pm today. 

MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AT ORRVALE THURSDAY EVENING WITH MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE FROM FRIDAY MORNING
MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT CASEY WEIR AND BENALLA

  • No significant rainfall has been recorded since 9:00 am Thursday in the Broken River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.
Broken River downstream of Casey Weir:
  • Moderate flooding may occur along the Broken River downstream of Casey Weir.
  • The Broken River at Orrvale is currently at 5.13 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Broken River at Orrvale is likely to exceed the minor flood level (6.80 m) Thursday evening. 
  • The river level may reach the moderate flood level (7.20 m) Friday morning.
Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir.
  • The Broken River at Casey Weir peaked at 2.44 metres around 10:00 am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 2.39 metres and steady, with minor flooding. 
  • The Broken River at Casey Weir is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.10 m) during Thursday.
Prepare for flooding now. Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.
What you should do:

  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to move household and/or shed items to higher ground, on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home and sheds is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Flooding above floor level of one single-storey home has been reported in Benalla today.
  • A small number of properties in Benalla became isolated, however falling river levels today have seen road access re-open.
ROADS CLOSED
  • The Midland Highway is closed at Stewarton.
  • Ackerley Ave and Arundel St sth (near the river) in Benalla are closed due to floodwater. 
  • The Monash Bridge is now fully open for traffic 
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Yarra River from Millgrove to Coldstream.

  • The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging 24 mm in the upper part of the catchment and 10 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Wednesday 04 October 2023.
  •  Rainfall totals of 1-5 mm are forecast for the catchment for Thursday 05 October 2023.
  • Water levels of the Yarra River at various locations are rising in response to the rain.
Yarra River from Millgrove to Coldstream:
  • The level of the Yarra River at Coldstream is currently at 5.25 metres, exceeding the Moderate Flood Level (5.10 metres), and rising slowly. 
  • It is expected to peak above the Moderate Flood Level (5.10 metres) later tomorrow morning, Friday 6th October.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Moderate flooding in the Yarra/Watts River catchment is expected to cause substantial inundation in the rural and/or urban areas, and disruption to traffic. Melba Highway at Yarra Glen is expected to be impacted by floodwaters.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Wonangatta River.

MODERATE FLOODING EASING ALONG WONNANGATTA RIVER AT WATERFORD

The flood peak along the Mitchell River is currently between Glenaladale and Rosehill.

No further rainfall of significance is expected across the Mitchell River catchment over the next few days.  

Wonnangatta River:
Moderate flooding is continuing to ease along the Wonnangatta River at Waterford following a peak just above the major flood level in the early hours of Thursday. 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds may be closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 05/10/2023 at 6:00pm or as the situation changes.

properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale.

BAIRNSDALE EXPECTED TO EXCEED MAJOR FLOOD LEVEL IN THE NEXT FEW HOURS

The flood peak along the Mitchell River is currently between Glenaladale and Rosehill.

No further rainfall of significance is expected across the Mitchell River catchment over the next few days.

Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale:
Major flooding is expected along the Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale. 

The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale measured 6.44 metres and rising at 11pm on Thursday 5 October, with moderate flooding. 

The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale is expected to exceed the major flood level (6.50 m) in the next few hours. The river level is likely to peak near 6.60 metres early Friday morning.
Move to higher ground. Act now - immediately take actions to protect your life and property.
What you should do: 

  • Agricultural land may be impacted. Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.   
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Potential impacts on agricultural land including stock and fencing.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds may be closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 05/10/2023 at 6:00pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is for Parts of Tinamba, Tinamba West, Newry and surrounds. 
  • An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return. 
  • Dangerous flood water remains, continue to avoid flood-affected areas.
It is not safe for people to return to Parts of Tinamba, Tinamba West, Newry and surrounds. 
What you should do: 

If you have not already evacuated: 
  • Stay where you are and shelter in the highest location possible. 
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time. 
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance. 
If you have already evacuated: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued. 
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe. The Relief Centre is located at Gippsland Regional Sports Complex, 116 Cobains Road, Sale.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place until 12pm Friday 6th October.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flood waters are still present in the area.
  • Local road closures are in place. 
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT KIALLA WEST OVERNIGHT THURSDAY INTO FRIDAY

MINOR FLOODING EASING AT EUROA

The main flood peak along the Seven Creeks is approaching Kialla West. River levels at Euroa and upstream continue to ease.

No significant rainfall has been recorded in the 24 hours to 2:00 pm Thursday.

Minor flooding is occurring along the Seven Creeks to Euroa.

Seven Creeks at Euroa peaked at 4.00 metres around 11:45 am Wednesday 04 October, with moderate flooding. The river level is currently at 2.95 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Seven Creeks at Euroa is likely to fall below the minor flood level (2.50 metres) overnight Thursday into Friday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Ovens River Bright to Rocky Point.

Minor flooding continues along the Ovens River at Rocky Point and along the King River at downstream Lake William Hovell.

No significant rainfall is forecast across the Ovens and King Rivers catchment over the next few days.

Ovens River Bright to Rocky Point:
Minor flooding is easing along the Ovens River at Eurobin. Minor flooding is occurring along the Ovens River at Rocky Point. 

The Ovens River at Eurobin is currently at 4.33 metres and falling, below the minor flood level (4.50 m).

The Ovens River at Rocky Point peaked at 4.21 metres around 08:00 am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 3.74 metres and falling, above the minor flood level. The Ovens River at Rocky Point is likely to remain above the minor flood level (3.20 m) into Friday morning.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding may still affect areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may still be flooded.
  • Local roads may still be closed and low bridges may still be underwater.
  • Many roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding, especially the Great Alpine Rd at Yellow Creek near Wangaratta, travel via the Detour Road bypass. 
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 08:00 am or as the situation changes.

  • Moderate flooding is occurring along the Ovens River at Wangaratta, where river levels are nearing a peak slightly below the major flood level. 
  • Moderate flooding is easing along the King River at Docker Rd Bridge. Minor flooding continues along the Ovens River at Rocky Point and along the King River at downstream Lake William Hovell.
  • No significant rainfall is forecast across the Ovens and King Rivers catchment over the next few days.

King River:
Moderate flooding is occurring along the King River.

No latest river level observations are currently available at downstream Lake William Hovell. The King River downstream Lake William Hovell is likely to remain above the minor flood level (1.80 m) during Friday.

The King River at Docker Rd Bridge peaked at 4.06 metres around 04:00 am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 3.99 metres and falling, above the moderate flood level. The King River at Docker Rd Bridge is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (3.95 m) Friday morning. The river level is likely to remain above the minor flood level (3.70 m) into Friday afternoon.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground if still safe to do so.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:

Yesterday's Community Update meeting was streamed live over Facebook and recorded at 2pm yesterday. Due to current flooding closing roads etc this "virtual" meeting with the latest information has been recorded for further sharing. Please find attached a YouTube link to this video: Wangaratta Video Update 5 Oct 2023  

  • Flooding above the floor level of homes is unlikely, however flooding of low lying sheds is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Flooding along rural farmland along the river flats.
In the Cheshunt to Edi area impacts range from:
Minor Flood level:
  • Dry Creek commences flowing over farmland from Queens Creek to King River. 
  • Gentle Annie Caravan Park monitoring the King River approaching the top of the bank.
  • Whitfield-Wangaratta Rd at Edi commences flooding.
  • At Cheshunt, King River at the top of the bank. King Valley roadside flooding commences at Cheshunt.
  • Low lying farmland (Cheshunt-Edi) commences flooding.
  • Local roadside flooding along King Valley Rd
Moderate flood level: 2.3 m on the Cheshunt gauge
  • Large areas of farmland flooding along the King River.
  • Johnsons Bridge on Lake Buffalo-Whitfield Road (Black Range Creek) closes due to inundation. 
  • Land inundated where Black Range Creek joins the King River.
In the Docker Road area:
At the Moderate flood level: of 3.95 m, 
  • Water starts flooding over the road at the Docker-Carboor Rd between Wangaratta-Whitfield Road & Oxley-Meadow Creek Road.
  • Low lying farmland flooding.
  • Local residents have an alternative way out.

Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for additional road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 08:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au

  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

For health information and support contact the below organisations: Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. Kids Helpine on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte.
  • The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging 24 mm in the upper part of the catchment and 10 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Wednesday 04 October 2023. 
  • Rainfall totals of 1-5 mm are forecast for the catchment for Thursday 05 October 2023.
  • Water levels of the Yarra River and Watts Rivers at various locations are rising in response to the rain.
Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte:
  • The level of the Yarra River at Yarra Glen is currently at 4.05 metres, approaching the Minor Flood Level (4.10 metres), and rising slowly. It is expected to peak around the Moderate Flood level (4.60 metres) tomorrow morning, Friday 6th October.
  • The level of the Yarra River at Christmas Hills is currently at 1.49 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (3.00 metres), and rising slowly. It is expected to peak around the Minor Flood Level on Saturday 7th October.
  • The level of the Yarra River at Warrandyte is currently at 1.65 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (3.00 metres), and rising slowly.It is expected to peak around the Minor Flood Level on Saturday 7th October.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.

  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT KIEWA (MAIN STREAM) AND BANDIANA   MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT BANDIANA FRIDAY AFTERNOON

Moderate flooding has eased at Mongans Bridge, where minor flooding is continuing. Minor flooding is occurring at Kiewa (Main Stream) and at Bandiana.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, up to 45 mm of rainfall has been recorded across the Kiewa catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for today.

Moderate flooding may occur along the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.

The Kiewa River at Kiewa (Main Stream) is currently at 3.36 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 

The Kiewa River at Kiewa (Main Stream) is likely to remain above the minor flood level (3.30 m) during Thursday. 

The Kiewa River at Bandiana is currently at 2.88 metres and rising, above the minor flood level. 

The Kiewa River at Bandiana is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.80 m) during Thursday. The river level may reach the moderate flood level (3.10 m) Friday afternoon.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Broken River to Benalla

MINOR FLOODING OCCURING AT CASEY WEIR AND BENALLA

No significant rainfall has been recorded since 9:00 am Thursday in the Broken River catchment.
No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Broken River to Benalla:
  • Minor flooding is occuring along the Broken River to Benalla.
  • The Broken River at Benalla is currently at 3.24 metres and steady, above the minor flood level. 
  • The Broken River at Benalla is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) during Thursday.
Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir:
  • Minor flooding is occuring along the Broken River Benalla to Casey Weir.
  • The Broken River at Casey Weir peaked at 2.44 metres around 10:00am Thursday 05 October and is currently at 2.39 metres and steady, with minor flooding. 
  • The Broken River at Casey Weir is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.10 m) during Thursday.
Broken River downstream of Casey Weir:
  • Moderate flooding may occur along the Broken River downstream of Casey Weir.
  • The Broken River at Orrvale is currently at 5.13 metres and rising, below the minor level. 
  • The Broken River at Orrvale is likely to exceed the minor flood level (6.80 m) Thursday evening. 
  • The river level may then reach the moderate flood level (7.20 m) Friday morning.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding may still be in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of one single-storey home has been reported in Benalla today.
  • A small number of properties in Benalla became become isolated, however falling river levels today have seen road access re-open.
ROAD CLOSURES
  • The Midland Highway is closed at Stewarton
  • Ackerley Ave and Arundel Street South (river end) in Benalla has been closed due to floodwater. 
  • Benalla-Tatong Road (Samaria Road) closed due to flooding between Shawbrook Avenue and Hume Freeway Overpass
  • The Monash Bridge is now re-opened to traffic in both directions.

    For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

- The river level may then reach the moderate flood level (7.20 m) Friday morning.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT KIEWA (MAIN STREAM) AND BANDIANA   MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT BANDIANA FRIDAY AFTERNOON   

Moderate flooding has eased at Mongans Bridge, where minor flooding is continuing. Minor flooding is occurring at Kiewa (Main Stream) and at Bandiana.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, up to 45 mm of rainfall has been recorded across the Kiewa catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for today.

The Kiewa River at Mongans Bridge is currently at 2.73 metres and falling, above the minor flood level (2.40 metres).

This situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 06/10/2023 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

MAJOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SALE WHARF LATE FRIDAY MORNING

The main flood peak along the Thomson River is now at Bundalaguah. Major flooding is possible at Sale Wharf late Friday morning as upstream floodwaters combine from the Macalister and Thomson Rivers.

No significant rainfall is forecast across the Thomson River catchment over the next few days. Forecasts will be further refined as upstream peaks are observed.

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:
Major flooding may occur along the Thomson River downstream of Wandocka. The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is currently at 1.90 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is expected to exceed the minor flood level (2.40 m) overnight Thursday into Friday. 

The river level is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (3.00 m) early Friday morning and may reach the major flood level (4.00 m) late Friday morning.

People located in the Port of Sale should follow the advice in the separate VicEmergency message.
Move to higher ground. Act now - immediately take actions to protect your life and property. People located in the Port of Sale area should Evacuate Immediately - check VicEmergency for a separate message.
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to move household items to higher ground, on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.     
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-storey home is likely to occur in many locations.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • This flood may be similar to June 2012, which resulted in significant flooding of communities.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 05/10/23 at 10:00pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
